abstract.para: &app; is an enhanced gettext po file editor for the GNOME desktop environment.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; offers you a comfortable graphical interface to edit gettext po files. It allows you to easily navigate among fuzzy, translated and untranslated messages and has a status bar displaying the number of messages for each category.

&app; features loading and saving of compressed po files and opening of remote files via Gnome-VFS. Moreover, the application makes it possible to merge an outdated po file with a recent pot file, all from the graphical interface!
The autotranslate function allows you to teach &app; msgid and msgstr pairs from a set of translated po files and then translate a new project using this translation memory.

sect1.title: Using &app;
sect1.para: &app; is a full featured graphical environment that makes it possible to translate po files painlessly. This section describes basic usage of &app;.

sect2.title: Basic usage
sect2.para:
The Main window is divided into three main area:
The menubar allows you the access the application menu.
The toolbars allow you quick access to frequently used file management, navigation and compile functions.
The workspace allows you to visualize and edit the messages contained in the po file.

sect3.title: Configuration
sect3.para:
&app; settings can be modified by choosing
Edit Preferences
menuitem.

sect3.title: Loading a po file
sect3.para:
To load a po file, use the
File Open...
menuitem. It will bring up the &app; -- open po file dialog box. Browse through your computer filesystem, choose the po file you wish to open and click OK.

&app; offers you the possibility to open po files using the Gnome-VFS subsystem. This means that you may use URIs to access files on a remote system. Currently supported URIs are:
local file:// URI as in file://localhost/path_to_file
remote http:// URI as in http://www.kabalak.net/gtranslator/gtranslator.pot
remote ftp:// URI as in ftp://ftp.somewhere.org/pub/tr.po

note.title: Opening compressed po files
note.para: &app; can open compressed po files. Click on the Open icon. This brings up the Open po file dialog box. Choose a compressed po file (can be identified by its .gz extension). Click on OK. If gzip is installed on your system, you may open gzip compressed files.

sect3.title: File management toolbar
sect3.para: The file management toolbar lets you access frequently used file management funcions quickly.

sect3.title: Navigation toolbar
sect3.para: The navigation toolbar allows you to navigate among messages. It also lets you search for strings, or search and replace strings.

sect2.title: Menu Bar
sect2.para: The menu bar, located at the top of the Main Window, contains the following menus:

listitem.para:
This menu contains:
AltC
Compile
This compiles the current po file.
F5
Update
This updates your po file from the sources.
F10
Autotranslate
This translates you po file automagically, using the learn buffers and the gettext domain available.
F3
Open
This opens a po file.
F?
Open from URI
This opens a po file via the FTP or the HTTP protocol.
CtrlS
Save
This saves your file.
CtrlShiftS
Save as...
This saves your po file under a different name.
Restore
This restores your po file to the last saved state.
CtrlW
Close
This closes your file.
Recent files
This shows a list of your recently opened po files.
CtrlE
Export to UTF-8
This exports your po file to UTF-8 encoding.
CtrlI
Import from UTF-8
This imports a UTF-8 encoded file.
CtrlQ
Exit
This quits the application.

This undoes your last change.

CtrlX

sect2.title: Available commandline options
sect2.para: &app; understands a number of command line options:

listitem.para: Shows you a short help message on the command line.
Shows you the version of &app;.
Lets you define the display to start &app; on.
Prints out a htmlized output file (you must give the html output filename as the next argument) of the po file.
An example would be: &app; --webalize=output.html xy.po
Sets the syntax color scheme to the given file.
For example: &app; --scheme=Schemefile
Lets you define a standard geometry string to which the gtranslator window will conform.
An example call would be: &app; --geometry="320x240+0+0" xy.po (This opens gtranslator at "+0+0", the left upper corner, with a size of 320x240).

sect1.title: Customization
sect1.para:
To change the application settings, select
Edit Preferences... . This opens the Preferences dialog.
The properties in the Personal information tab are:

listitem.para: Fill in your name. This information will be saved in the po file.
Fill in your e-mail address. This information will be saved in the po file.
Choose a query domain from the drop down list.

sect1.para: The properties in the Language settings tab are:

listitem.para: Choose from the dropdown list the target language. &app; fills in the rest of the form with default values for the given language. You may modify the preset values, but usually you can safely use the default settings.
This field displays the ISO 639-2 language code used for the language chosen above. The name of the PO file will be based on this setting.
This field displays the email address used by the language team.
The Charset field displays the encoding used to store the po file. &app; offers you a default setting.

note.title: Using alternate encodings
note.para: Default charset settings offered by &app; can be used safely when translating po files for the GNOME 2.x platform. GNOME 2.x uses UTF-8 encoding for all languages, thus you need the alter the defaults when translating for 1.x platforms.

sect1.para: Any changes you have made will be instantly effective.
